thread.title: Learning experience for BC in Death Valley
thread.title_full: Learning experience for BC in Death Valley | Boston Herald

author: Rich Thompson
title: Learning experience for BC in Death Valley
text:
CLEMSON, S.C. — Boston College coach Steve Addazio elected to grow his franchise against an elite Atlantic Coast Conference program in the hardest house on the schedule.
Addazio gave his many untested first- and second-year players a dose of ACC reality in Saturday night’s 34-17 loss to No. 5 Clemson at Death Valley.
“We had four freshmen (offensive) linemen in there at one point, we had three freshmen defensive linemen, two freshmen wide receivers and (freshman) Jordan Gowins in there at tailback,” Addazio said. “We played them all and this was a great opportunity for them in this kind of environment to get valuable game experience.
“I thought they, for the most part, handled it well and I thought our team played very hard.”
Freshman quarterback Jeff Smith was the most scrutinized member of Addazio’s youth movement. The third-year coach thought Smith made achievable strides in his first career start against the No. 13 defense in the nation.
Smith had platooned with redshirt freshman Troy Flutie after starter Darius Wade suffered a fractured left ankle Sept. 18 against Florida State. The inherent flaws in game planning for two quarterbacks were exposed and exploited in consecutive ACC low-scoring losses to Duke and Wake Forest.
Smith completed 7-of-22 for 88 yards in a controlled passing game. He showed tremendous dexterity avoiding the Tigers’ relentless pass rush and made good decisions with the football on broken plays.
Smith gave BC a 7-0 lead on a 4-yard touchdown pass to fullback Bobby Wolford with 8:13 to play in the first. He scored the game’s final points on a 1-yard rush with 1:29 to play in the fourth.
“I think (Smith) did a great job as far as handling the atmosphere and we all stuck together to fight the atmosphere,” junior tailback Myles Willis, who led the BC ground game with 88 yards on 15 carries, said. “He prepared all week so we were prepared for it.
“I’m sure this is what he’s dreamed and once your dreams become a reality you don’t have time to be nervous.”
Smith also gained a real-time perspective on what it takes to be a successful quarterback in the ACC. Clemson sophomore Deshaun Watson eviscerated the top-ranked defense in the country with an undetectable fusion of short, intermediate and deep passes.
Watson completed 27-of-41 passes for 420 yards and three touchdowns with two interceptions. Sophomore wide receiver Artavis Scott was Watson’s primary target with 10 receptions for 162 yards and touchdown.
“They are very electrifying in the pass game so we knew they were going to try and throw the ball around today,” senior free safety Justin Simmons, who finished with nine tackles and an interception that set the Eagles up for their first touchdown, said. “I don’t want to justify a loss, but I do see improvement on both sides of the ball and we just have to get back to work.”
